direction.raw_text: The high magnesium content of these natural springs will hold anyone up. Although it is not a resort for infirm types I am extending you my personal invitation to come visit in the off- season." (putting the letter aside) I'm only welcome in the "off- season." Eugene and Stanley approach the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Roosevelt, we got bad news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? F
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the boat... it got banged up real bad tied to the dock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How bad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think you can stay there anymore. ranklin absorbs this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it's a blessing in disguise, Mr. Roosevelt. I don't know about you, but I'm homesick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm sick of home. (to Louis) Where's the letter from Peabody?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't be serious? He hands Franklin the letter who rereads it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not miracle waters? I've drunk the oil of monkey glands, been zapped with electricity and hung upside down in harnesses. After all that, this sounds downright peaceful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't quite picture you in the back woods of Georgia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do you picture me, Louis?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pennsylvania Avenue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: President, Louis? I can't visit the bathroom without a team of associates to help pull my pants down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give it a little time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a reason they say a man runs for office. (a beat) I'm going to Georgia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. A TRAIN CAR - DAY 34                                                               34 Franklin and Eleanor sit next to one another. Franklin is now shaved and cleaned up considerably. However, the tension between them is palpable. Eleanor knits furiously while talking. Franklin looks out the window at African-American FIELD HANDS hard at work in the red clay hills of Georgia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James has been doing so much better now that Elliot has joined him at Groton. They've put their differences behind them and have become a real team. Franklin observes two YOUNG BOYS, African-American, running alongside the slow-moving train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two peas in a pod. Last week they were both in the infirmary with the F         same cold. ranklin eyes a wagon pulled by a mule. The driver, a FARMER, takes off his hat and wipes his brow in the hot sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meanwhile, any suggestion I make to Anna for her future -- she dismisses me. I am going to have to enlist your support in this, Franklin. She listens to you. She looks over at Franklin and sees that he is staring out the window, deep in thought -- not having heard a word she's said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. BULLOCHVILLE TRAIN STATION - GEORGIA - DAY 35                                                              35 TOM LOYLESS, 39, stands waiting by a car dressed in a white suit. Laconic, with a dry sense of humor, Tom is a man of few words whose poker face hides a true desperation. He holds a telegram from Franklin in his hand. As the train pulls in Tom looks for Franklin among the passengers making their exit. There are two different exits on the platform clearly marked WHITE and COLORED. Whites exit from the front of the train and Blacks from the rear. LIONEL PURDY, tiny, and dressed in a mailman's uniform, approaches Tom. Of indeterminate age and dubious intellect, his mail bag is almost as big as he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone important?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You might say so, Lionel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Roosevelt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Teddy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (patiently) No, he's dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. The STATIONMASTER approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom, your guest needs some assistance. We're gonna need some able-bodied men to move him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Lionel) Go over to the livery stable...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... and get the Collier boys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. A TRAIN CAR - DAY 36                                                                36 Franklin exits the train slung in a fireman's carry over the shoulder of ROY COLLIER, African-American, 29. His brother PETE, 27, is close behind, carrying luggage -- both hover at around 6' 4". Tom approaches. Franklin attempts to hide his embarrassment with good cheer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello! Hello! Mr. Loyless?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom, Mr. Roosevelt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you'd better call me Franklin. Still in the fireman's carry, Franklin extends his hand for Tom to shake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this is the Misses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call me Eleanor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pleased to make your acquaintance. Roy then carries him over to Tom's car and gingerly places him inside. Pete follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Tom) There's a trunk and a chair with the wheels, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll send a wagon right over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We got a wagon, sir. EXT. A COUNTRY ROAD - DAY 37                                                                37 Tom drives Franklin in front, Eleanor sits in the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Pine trees tower over the sides of the dirt road. In occasional clearings, Franklin spies barefoot children playing out in front of broken-down shacks. They stop their play to look at the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (covering his discomfort) Beautiful country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have you been manager of the Inn?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not long. They BANG over a large pothole. They all fly up and land hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got any paved roads?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No we don't. EXT. THE MERIWETHER INN - DAY 38                                                               38 Tom's car turns into a driveway. Franklin has a brochure for "The Meriwether Inn" opened in his lap. He tries to spy the building through the trees but cannot. He looks back at the brochure. The picture is of a lavish Victorian Hotel and the words, "Our renowned mineral hot springs can cure whatever ails you!" Franklin looks up and sees a three-story hideous green and yellow monstrosity leaning slightly to one side. Paint is peeling everywhere. What once were flower beds are overgrown with weeds. The car pulls to a stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll have a great deal of privacy. There are only a few guests right now as it's the off- season... I'm hoping to make some improvements by next Spring -- Franklin puts out his arm preventing Tom from getting out of the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (panicked) I... I can't stay here. This place is a wreck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look on the bright side. Most of your time will be spent in the water. (a beat) It's true, we've fallen on some hard times...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hard times? This is a disaster! It should be condemned! Tom's southern manners are being put to the test, but he stays remarkably calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, we've seen better days. (a beat) But then I imagine so have you. Franklin blinks incomprehensibly at Tom and what he has just said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm happy to drive you back to the train station right now, if that's what you want. They lock eyes. Franklin wonders if Tom's bluffing, but he can't tell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a low voice) Fire. I'm frightened of fire. I can't get out if I'm upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've got options. EXT. MERIWETHER INN GROUNDS - DAY 39                                                                39 Tom's car is now parked in front of a group of small cottages. Roy and Pete's horse drawn wagon is behind it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. COTTAGE - DAY 40                                                               40 Tom and Pete open a set of shutters over the windows of a tiny cottage. Franklin and Eleanor sit in the car, watching. INT. COTTAGE - DAY 41                                                               41 Sheets cover the furniture, cobwebs span the beams and dust particles fill the air. As Tom maneuvers the wheelchair through the front door, Franklin notices a broken window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (caustic) Well ventilated, at least. Roy enters with a suitcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do you want this, Mr. Roosevelt?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bedroom, Roy, thank you. He looks after Roy as he exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom, this young man appears quite competent. Would you ask him if he'd like to stay on as my valet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (politely) Why don't you ask him yourself? He tips his hat and goes outside. EXT. DRIVEWAY - DAY 42                                                               42 Pete, alone, drives the wagon past the Inn and out onto the road. INT. COTTAGE - DAY 43                                                               43 Eleanor stands in the middle of the tiny living room stunned by the squalor. She speaks to Franklin who is changing in the other room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is madness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No doubt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me again, Franklin, why are we here? Franklin is wheeled out by Roy, now changed into a bathing suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the waters. Are you coming? EXT. A DIRT PATH - DAY 44                                                                44 Roy wheels Franklin while Tom walks in front of them leading the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Roosevelt want to swim?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Roosevelt doesn't know how. Franklin takes in the surroundings. Deserted horse stables in total ruin and tennis courts covered with underbrush mar the landscape. 45
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . POOL - DAY An immense, T-shaped pool rimmed in concrete. The bluish water is clear and sparkling and a delicate steam rises out of the warmth. A MOTHER, eyeing Franklin approaching in his wheelchair, comes to the edge of the pool and coaxes her CHILDREN out of the water. AUNT SALLY, an ancient, gaunt, African American woman, stands guard by the edge of the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Roosevelt, I'd like you to meet Aunt Sally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aunt Sally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good day, sir. I have towels for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Roy wheels Franklin as close to the rim of the pool as possible. Tom lends his assistance and both he and Roy HOIST Franklin out of the chair and place him at the edge, letting his feet dangle in the warm water. Twisting on his massive arms, Franklin lowers himself cautiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now give it a minute. You'll see that the mineralization makes the water more buoyant. The crippled boy who swam here was actually able to walk in the water. Franklin's legs flop as his useless feet touch the shallow bottom. Crushed, all hope drains from his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't even stand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, not yet. EXT. CABIN - NIGHT 46                                                                46 Roy sleeps on a couch on the front porch. Crickets hum. INT. CABIN - CONTINUING 47                                                                47 Eleanor tosses and turns on a roll away bed. 48
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CABIN BEDROOM - CONTINUING Franklin lies in bed staring up at the ceiling. INT. MERIWETHER INN - DINING ROOM - DAY 49                                                                49 A handful of guests are spread out in a huge dining room. Franklin and Eleanor sit together. He is eating heartily, but Eleanor merely moves her food around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is simply revolting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not very good, but it is mysterious. (holding out his plate) What in the world do you think they've poured over this chicken? Or is it possum? Eleanor sizes Franklin up. She knows this is a preamble. H
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to stay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: New York has the best doctors and hospitals in the country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need something new.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This isn't about getting better is it? You don't want to come home. You don't want to live with us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I refuse to be a burden to anyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not a burden, you're my husband. e reaches out and takes her hand in his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to offer you the freedom you once so generously offered me. (she pulls it away) All you've ever known is duty. To me and to a political career that unless I can walk no longer exists. You've been exemplary. Now I'm telling you you're free to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (her voice rising) No. (a beat) I don't want freedom. I want a marriage. I want a life with you. Franklin won't let himself believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't imagine what you think that life is going to be. This takes the wind out of Eleanor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Franklin... it's not up to me to imagine, it's up to you. Eleanor folds her napkin and gets up from the table. EXT. COTTAGE DRIVEWAY - DAY 50                                                               50 Pete helps Eleanor into his livery wagon. Franklin watches from the porch as Eleanor rides away. Her suitcase slides across the open wagon bed, as the wagon makes the tight turn from the driveway onto the main road. ON ELEANOR Looking out -- straight ahead. ON FRANKLIN Alone and scared as he watches the wagon fade from sight. 51
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HYDE PARK - DAY Eleanor is pouring tea for Louis, who is seated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for stopping by, Mr. Howe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you might want to see a friendly face. (off the silence) So how's our boy doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, he's enjoying the waters very much. He... (suddenly overwhelmed) I think we've lost him. Her pent-up tears burst in a free-flow. Louis leads her to a nearby settee and hands her his handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please excuse me, Mr. Howe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you think it's time you called me Louis?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Louis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe we've been going about this all wrong. He's down there to be alone so let's give him what he wants. We change our focus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To what? Louis smiles, knowingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To you. EXT. COTTAGES - SUNSET 52                                                             52 The row of abandoned cottages look strangely pretty, aglow in the setting sun. 53
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COTTAGE - CONTINUOUS Franklin is seated on the ramshackle porch in his chair. His cigarette hangs from his lip as he mixes martinis in a glass milk bottle. He pours one for Tom, then himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To your mineral pool, or whatever you call it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warm Springs. They clink their glasses. Tom takes a polite sip, then chokes back the bad taste.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too strong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven't been in a drinking mood lately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, its the most god-awful martini I've ever tasted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you always this direct, Tom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I never tasted a martini this bad before. Franklin takes another sip, checking. It tastes fine to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (hurt) Everyone likes my martinis...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So they say. INT. COTTAGE - MORNING 54                                                              54 Franklin's bed is already empty. EXT. POOL - MORNING 55                                                              55 Aunt Sally is seated, talking with Roy while Franklin lies on his back in the water, swimming. All his movement comes from his shoulders and arms. The morning sun streams down on him. Tom sits off to one side reading the newspaper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me more about what that boy did, Aunt Sally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, first he'd always swim over to the side of the pool and hold himself there -- make sure he righted himself. Then... before he knew it... he'd be standing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it was only that easy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you make it hard. Get over to the side of that pool and grab it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ( humoring her) Yes, ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you got to remember how you did it. Franklin holds the edge of the pool, closing his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a nervous laugh) I'm standing. His laughter gets stronger. Tom, Aunt Sally and Roy look on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm standing. The release is powerful as Franklin dissolves into tears. EXT. COTTAGE PORCH - EVENING 56                                                               56 Tom, who's been mixing cocktails, hands Franklin a drink and lifts his glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To standing on your own two feet! They clink and drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This water could be the cure -- the cure! In six months I could be up and walking! Lionel, the mailman, comes down the path carrying a flashlight, reading an open letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evening folks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cocktail, Lionel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't. I'm working for the federal government.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the more reason. (shoving a drink at him) Sort of late for the mail, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not for me it isn't. Got a whole packet of clippings for you, Mr. Roosevelt. From a Mr. Howe. New York Times, Journal-American... don't know what else. He hands an already opened letter to Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your mother wants to know when you're coming home. She says they got swimming pools in Hyde Park. She's mad as all hell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reading other people's mail is not only impolite, it's illegal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sheriff don't mind. He likes I read his mail. Saves him the time. Plus a lot of folks around here can't read, so it's more a public service, really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Astonishing. Thank you, Lionel. He hands Lionel a letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reading) "Miss Missy LeHand." Who's she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you must know, she's my social secretary. (to Tom) I'm having her come down. Lionel reaches into his bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Almost forgot... your wife wrote the nicest letter. She's gonna make a speech at the League of Women Voters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me that. (
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He hands the letter to Franklin who immediately begins reading.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Tom) Says she's gonna keep the Roosevelt name alive. Least till he starts walkin' and all. Lionel takes the letter Franklin just handed him, opens it, flicks his flashlight back on and continues on his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (studying the letter) This is so unlike Eleanor. She's terrified of crowds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 57                                                                 57 INT. HALLWAY - DAY Louis and Eleanor approach a set of double doors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are facing imminent disaster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I take full responsibility if you hyperventilate or faint. They enter the room. INT. MEETING ROOM - CONTINUOUS 58                                                                 58 At a lectern, behind which a banner reads "LEAGUE OF WOMEN VOTERS," the CHAIRWOMAN sees them and waves them forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, here she is now. Ladies, Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt. A small crowd of about two dozen women offer up polite, but scant applause for Eleanor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good afternoon. I am so pleased to be invited here today. looking down at her cards) Too often.... A PHOTOGRAPHER snaps a picture which throws Eleanor off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too often... She stops. The pause is deadly. Louis looks ready to jump out a window. Eleanor continues, her voice still pitched too high.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too often the great decisions are originated and given form in bodies made up wholly of men... Slowly, she begins to find her voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So that whatever political value women have to offer is shunted aside... without expression. T his is a mistake. She looks up from her cards and stares at the audience... and for the first time speaks spontaneously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think this might be the reason I am having such a difficult time giving voice to my own thoughts here today. The immediacy of her self-effacing comment charms the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm reminded of what someone once said about looking at an elephant. That it is impossible to ever see an entire elephant from one place -- you must walk around it. If our elected leaders are to be truly effective then they must be willing to go out of their way to look beyond what is right in front of them. To see the entire elephant. And for that... they need our help. The ladies applaud her, much to her relief. Louis beams. LATER At a reception following the speech, Eleanor and the Chairwoman are drinking tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was so moving, Mrs. Roosevelt. The Child Welfare Amendment could use someone with your passion. You must consider being our spokesperson. Eleanor looks to Louis who nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. It would be an honor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wonderful. 59
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . POOL - DAY Franklin is attempting to walk in the water, working diligently. Tom watches him from a few paces back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I walked five steps today!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Congratulations. Listen, Franklin, I got word a local reporter wants to do a story on you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm hardly newsworthy these days. (a beat) How did he find out I'm here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Small town -- word gets out. It probably won't amount to more than a provincial puff piece but it might give us some free publicity for the Inn. Franklin looks at Tom knowing full well he's arranged this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, I know the gentleman. I'm doing him a favor. You know, I used to be a journalist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you mean all this time I've been talking to a newspaper man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not anymore. I got in a bit of trouble in Atlanta. Seems some of the editorial pieces I wrote offended the sensibilities of a local civic group. So I needed to lay low for a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a beat) You mean the Klan? Good God, Tom...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thankfully, Mr. George Foster Peabody gave me this job...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that explains a few things. For the life of me, I couldn't figure out why someone like you was running this -- TOM Rat-trap?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (laughing, swimming off) I was going to say dump, but rat- trap fits nicely. EXT. FRANKLIN'S COTTAGE - FRONT PORCH - DAY 60                                                               60 Franklin is seated -- but not in his wheelchair. He wears long pants even though it's blisteringly hot. CLEBURNE GREGORY, 28, sits across from Franklin -- a second string reporter in a three-piece suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now in 1920 when you were running for Vice-President...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't imagine your readers are interested in ancient history. Cox and I lost the election by a wide margin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was only a few years ago, Mr. Roosevelt... H 43.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now it's the waters extra minerals plus its warmth that makes all the difference. At 90 degrees I can work my muscles for hours and not get cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Assistant Secretary of the Navy during the Great War did you condone the use of...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I forgot one more thing you will need to write down. Poor circulation is a chronic problem for people in my condition. Gregory looks at Franklin. It's clear he's not going to get the interview he came for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So... you think it could be a cure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you're hopeful?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I am. INT. COTTAGE - NIGHT 61                                                                61 Franklin is laid out on the bed as Roy slides the braces off his legs. Roy unlaces his shoes and slips them off his feet. e is about to put them under the bed when Franklin motions for Roy to hand them to him. Still flat on his back, Franklin luxuriates in the rich leather cobbled by hand. He examines their smooth, immaculate soles... worn but never walked in. INT. COTTAGE - MORNING 62                                                                62 A newspaper clipping of Eleanor in her speech to the League is taped to the wall. We hear the sound of an Underwood typewriter clacking away and Franklin's voice, dictating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Therefore, a formal questionnaire should be composed in order so we may hear from all recent delegates as to how we can do better in '28 to present a more united front. Signed, Franklin Roosevelt, etc., etc. MISSY LE HAND, 30, is sitting at a card table, typing. Brunette with some early gray, she is sturdy in build with a plain but friendly face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very good. Do you want this out today?    F RANKLIN Tomorrow will be fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Missy, and c.c. that to Louis. Missy rises with a stack of envelopes and heads out. Roy enters with a plate of pancakes in front of Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hungry, Mr. Roosevelt?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who do you write to every morning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Different people I knew in politics. Just in case they ever want me back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you'll be ready when you get your legs workin' again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . There is a knock at the screen door. An earnest young man, BENJAMIN PRENDERGAST, 18, is peering in. He has a newspaper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, are you Mr. Roosevelt?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Who are you? Roy opens the door to Prendergast, who enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is Benjamin Prendergast. I've come to see if you could speak at this year's graduation ceremony at the schoolhouse. You being so famous and all. Prendergast unfolds the newspaper. There is a picture of Franklin under the heading "FRANKLIN ROOSEVELT SWIMS HIS WAY TO HEALTH!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be damned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you be available?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking up) When? Next spring?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next week. We only have a four month school year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is that possible?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tax dollars only cover that much.
