direction.raw_text: It's a waste. An awful waste. Franklin takes a beat -- the weight of this sinking in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the acreage here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roughly twelve hundred or so. Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to buy it. I think it would make one hell of an investment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Investment?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twelve hundred acres? Enough for two resorts, don't you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It would take money. There's a lot of land, rebuilding the inn, adding ramps and so many people can't pay...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (undeterred) Do you think old Peabody will sell?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll sell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you be so sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you taken a look at this place?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. TOM'S OFFICE   - DAY 93                                                               93 Franklin sits in his chair at a desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peabody you old reprobate! How are you? Tom is pacing back and forth
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll never guess why I'm calling. EXT. MERIWETHER INN - MAIN ENTRANCE - DAY 94                                                               94 Helena is training a group of YOUNG MEN how to lift and carry using a raven haired young woman, ELOISE HUTCHISON, 18, as the test model. She sits shyly in her wheelchair before them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woodhall, this is Eloise. Lift her gently. WOODHALL BUSEY, 17, has bright red hair and a face full of freckles. Over six feet tall he has spent his life working in the fields.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. He picks Eloise up effortlessly, then sets her back down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very good! Watch her braces. Woodhall kneels before Eloise like Prince Charming, carefully straightening out her legs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're light as a ... He notices the long jagged scars along Eloise's wrists. Eloise, sensing his eyes, self-consciously pulls down her sleeves. He stares at her questioningly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking away) I was a dancer... Tom and Franklin come out. Franklin gives a questioning look to Helena, pondering how these boys have suddenly appeared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good news... I raided the pool hall. I call them my Push Boys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome Push Boys! Good day, Eloise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Mr. Roosevelt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want to tell them your good news? Franklin is smiling like the cat that ate the canary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's hardly a done deal, but for better or worse, you may be looking at the new owner of this God- forsaken place. INT. COTTAGE - EVENING 95                                                             95 A free wheeling game of poker. Heavy with cigarette and cigar smoke, Franklin, Tom, Fred, Jake and Pat are playing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Polio's always going to be a losing financial proposition, but it doesn't mean you shouldn't buy the place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am buying it. Make no mistake about that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good for you, Doc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you don't mind my asking, how will people pay for the services you are going to offer here? Most people with polio have a hard enough time making ends meet as it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gently) The boy makes a good point, Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not everything in this world has to be about profits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll see your twenty-five and raise you twenty-five.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon will ya! The night's still young.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's twenty-five cents not twenty- five dollars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't mind him, Tom. He's a cheap bastard. Fred and Pat fold immediately as does Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too rich for my blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Tom) Fine! Here's your twenty-five! You better have something. They eyeball each other. Gunfight at the O.K. Corral.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it. I was bluffing. Gleefully, Jake slaps his hands together and rakes in the pot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (handing Franklin a fresh deck) Your deal, Doc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very well. Gentlemen, the game is Five Card Stud, sevens are wild. Everyone groans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sevens are wild and you can all go to Hell! EXT. MERIWETHER INN - GROUNDS - DAWN 96                                                             96 The sun is about to rise. Tom's car is parked in front of the Inn, pulled up very close to the main entrance. The trunk is open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Tom, struggling with a suitcase, comes down the ramp. He deposits it in the trunk and then walks precariously back up the ramp, having difficulty navigating the incline. He goes back into the house for one last bag. When he comes out, he's surprised by what he sees -- FRANKLIN (O.S.) Where do you think you're going? Franklin is being pushed by Roy in his wheelchair. They are both dressed in pajamas and bathrobes, though Franklin has a blanket around his shoulders to shield him from the morning chill. Tom is caught. This is everything he wanted to avoid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Going to Asheville to see my parents. From the sight of Tom's car stuffed with luggage, it is clear he is not coming back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't do this without you... we're only just beginning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You. (You're beginning, not me. a beat) I've got cancer, Franklin. It's spread everywhere. Franklin is stunned -- utterly thrown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I'll take you to the best doctors. We'll go to Atlanta right now -- TOM I've seen the best doctors. When you were in New York they opened me up for the second time. Now I just want to die in the bed I was born. Franklin is struggling with this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to do great things. This place has an identity now -- a purpose. It has you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Any guard Franklin had is gone. He reaches out and takes Tom by the sleeve slipping his hand into Tom's gripping it tightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take care of yourself, Roy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God be with you, Mr. Loyless. Tom takes one last look at Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You never pitied me. Thank you for that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the contrary, I envy you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will miss you all the days of my life. Tom gets into his car and looks at Franklin with a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good luck, Franklin. With a wave he slowly lurches down the long driveway and turns onto the main road. Franklin watches the car until it is out of sight. INT. HYDE PARK, NEW YORK - LIBRARY - DAY 97                                                                97 Sara paces wildly, waving a letter at Eleanor and Louis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wants to use his entire trust fund to buy that... leper colony!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin has invited Louis and me to see the work he's been doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (derisively) Work! Playing in a pool all day long? Squandering his birthright on a group of fawning strangers? I consider this your fault, Eleanor!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I beg your pardon, Mama?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have indulged him and this is the result.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (challenging her) Indulged him? I have indulged him? Sara looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a grown man who makes his own decisions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he does not need to buy it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it's of any comfort to you, I agree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm against it as well. It will consume too much of his time and energy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then it is settled. We tell him no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it is not settled. We must hear him out. Louis and I must see for ourselves the work that he has been doing then we will all discuss this further. (a beat) A nd tell him no. They all look at each other for a moment. For once they agree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps I have underestimated you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps you have. But that has been my fault, not yours. EXT. MERIWETHER INN - DAY 98                                                             98 Fred, on crutches, swings himself up using one side and then the next under Helena's supervision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent, Fred! Keep going... They are surrounded by many others, Franklin, Eloise, Woodhall, Pat and Jake. The BEEPING of a car horn gets their immediate attention. Roy leaps off the porch, skipping the stairs as his brother Pete drives up in Tom's car. He parks it and steps out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning, Mr. Roosevelt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peter, what are you doing with Tom's car?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was as sorry as anyone to hear about Mr. Loyless's passing. Wished he coulda' lived to see this!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Loyless had me come up and fetch this right after he brung it to Asheville. "Pete, he said, "Take this home and fix it up for Mr. Roosevelt."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pete... I can't drive a car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can now. Roy opens the passenger door and lifts Franklin into the driver's seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get on in and I'll teach ya'! He begins showing off a system of pulleys and levers that have been attached to both pedals. They thread through holes in a second dashboard, attached to polished wood knobs. It's a hand-controlled automobile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That one there is your brake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this here's the gas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hot damn! You got hand controls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is a thing of beauty! Franklin begins running his hands over the polished wood knobs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you got to push it real smooth or it goes all herky-jerky. Franklin excitedly turns the key and starts it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait, Mr. Roosevelt, you're not ready to drive yet!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yes I am! Franklin hits the gas as the car begins HALTING and JERKING the whole way down the driveway. Pete is yelling out instructions but Franklin ignores him. They all watch as he pulls away. As the car hits the end of the driveway Franklin reaches across Pete and opens his passenger door pushing him out. Franklin tears off alone -- out on his first solo spin. OVER MUSIC: EXT. COUNTRY ROAD - DAY 99    F                                                             99 ranklin is driving by himself with the top down, thrilled to be moving on his own. No one is pushing him. He's free. The car covers miles of farmland, passing pine forests, peach orchards and cotton fields.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : EXT. BULLOCHVILLE TRAIN STATION - MORNING 100                                                               100 A spent and anxious Eleanor, with Louis in tow, stands on the station platform, suitcase in hand. 76.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a far cry from Grand Central Station. They are both silent for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wire said someone would be here to pick us up. The sounds of tires screeching and a car horn cause them to turn around. It is Franklin, sitting in the driver's seat of his car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your chariot awaits, Madame! Louis promptly drops the luggage. Then he and Eleanor walk over to the car, taking in the hand-controls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When did you learn to drive this thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tuesday! 101
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRY ROAD - DAY Franklin drives wild and fast. Louis hat flies right off his head. Eleanor just holds on. EXT. MERIWETHER INN - DAY 102                                                               102 Franklin, Eleanor and Louis pull up to the Inn. Though the brush has been cleared and the trees are newly trimmed, it's still a wreck. Franklin is too proud to concede Louis and Eleanor's disappointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't wait to give you the tour! EXT. GROUNDS - DAY 103                                                               103 Franklin wheels himself along the circular driveway, pointing things out, almost manic in his energy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small schoolhouse will go there. We need it badly as many of the children are barred from the local schools due to their infirmities.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He points to a dilapidated gardener's shed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We also require a blacksmith's shop so we can craft braces here on the premises. I've found a wonderful local man who can make crutches and canes. His work is outstanding. Of course what is most desperately needed is a hospital. That's going to put my fund raising abilities to the test. Franklin wheels himself up a ramp to the Inn as Eleanor and Louis follow. INT. LOBBY - CONTINUOUS 104                                                               104 Surrounded by peeling wallpaper and threadbare furniture E Eleanor and Louis exchange glances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What exactly are you proposing, Franklin?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That this will be the first polio rehabilitation and treatment center in the world. My personal trust almost covers the price of the Inn and the surrounding land. There will be a modest tuition charged to the patients which should hold us over while I seek out investors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin, you're risking everything you have...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And there are other costs to consider.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama will see that the children are provided for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not speaking of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have found something here which makes waking up in the morning remotely bearable and the two of you stand there...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin, I need for you to be practical and realistic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (furious) Practical? I am trapped inside a body that no longer moves of my own volition. I am trying to be practical. Now either you're with me or against me. In or out!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care for ultimatums disguised as debate. Eleanor starts to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going? Eleanor! Get back here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will see you gentlemen tonight. She leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't talk to her like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh really? Are you an expert on this now? How should I speak to my wife, Louis?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With the respect she deserves. (a beat) Look, I don't deny the work you're doing here could be important -- FRANKLIN Could be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The issue is whether you want to run a rehabilitation center or whether you want to run for office again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I can walk, I'll run. EXT. POOL - DAY 105                                                            105 Eleanor approaches the pool. It is as quiet as a church. She is stunned to observe over a dozen tables set up in the water. On each table is a child or an adult polio wearing their bathing suit. Next to them is a Physical Therapist also in bathing attire conducting therapy. In hushed tones the Physical Therapists encourage and work the distressed limbs of the patients as Helena swims to each table overseeing the work being done. Eleanor sits down in a chair and watches fascinated. INT. DINING ROOM - EVENING 106                                                            106 The camera pans various tables revealing legs in braces, legs in wheelchairs, shapely legs, flaccid legs, children's legs... some reveal illicit romances, betrayed by secret hand holding and hands on thighs. Jake and a new physical therapist, MARY BETH, are particularly cozy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a very special night we're celebrating. At last we are together eating in this dining room! The hands come up and out from under the table, applauding. ON FRANKLIN He is in his wheelchair dressed in a jacket and tie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now please join me in welcoming Miss Jackie Mills, a new arrival along with her father, Samuel, all the way from Oakland, California.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE-UP ON JACKIE Eight years old with black hair. Her legs are in braces and she grips her father's hand tightly. ON FRANKLIN FRANKLIN Let us also take this opportunity to welcome our two able-bodied guests, Mr. Louis Howe and my better half, Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt. ON ELEANOR AND LOUIS Waving politely from their seats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now for the musical portion of our program...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute! I can't let this opportunity pass without saying out loud what a lot of us feel in our hearts right now. (a beat) You're a man among men, Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And women!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And children!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (laughing) It's a real democracy at Warm Springs -- everybody gets heard! (to Franklin) You listening? Eleanor, seated next to Franklin, watches as Franklin, in a rare moment of emotional nakedness, is at a loss for words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right then, if I may do the honors of presenting to you the lovely Miss Eloise Hutchison of Cottage C. Eloise wheels herself out. In a sweet, but untrained voice, she begins the introduction to her song:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (singing) "Think of what you're losing by constantly refusing to dance with me. Y Aou'd be the idol of France with me. nd yet you stand there And shake your foolish head dramatically, W hile I sit here so ecstatically. You just look and say emphatically: Not this season! There's a reason!" Some members of the audience begin to smile, knowing what's coming. Various STAFF step out from the kitchen to watch. Eloise is joined by three others -- all of them in wheelchairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (singing)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: won't dance! Don't ask me! I won't dance! Don't ask me; I won't dance, monsieur, with you." Simple, but clever choreography utilizing the wheelchairs, has the audience cheering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "My heart won't let my feet do C things they should do."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "You know what? You're lovely."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "And so what? I'm lovely."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "But oh! What you do to me! I'm like an ocean wave that's bumped on the shore; I feel so absolutely stumped on the floor!" This is too much for the crowd, including Franklin, Eleanor and Louis. They laugh and cry in equal measure at the sight of Eloise and her Chorus. The song finished, Franklin quiets down the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before we say good night, I understand our Royal-Taskmaster- in-Residence, Miss Mahoney, insists on having the last word. Helena rises from her seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think words describe adequately what Daisy and I would like to show all of you. (calling out) Are you ready, Daisy? Daisy's mother, Cecile, carries Daisy to the center of the room where Helena meets them. Helena bends down and removes Daisy's braces. The room is hushed. Daisy then begins to WALK tentatively towards her mother. ON FRANKLIN Overwhelmed by what is taking place. He looks around and takes in the sight of so many different faces... Some are beaming, some are fighting back tears, some look away... the sight of it almost too painful... a reminder of their own private battles. ON DAISY Only a step or two away from her mother she FALLS the short distance and lands in her mother's outstretched arms. WILD CHEERS go up in the room while Daisy's face glows with pride. She connects with Franklin, who matches her smile with his own -- genuine and beatific. INT. COTTAGE - BEDROOM - NIGHT 107                                                               107 Roy lifts Franklin out of the wheelchair and on to the bed. Eleanor enters holding a lit candle. Roy is about to begin Franklin's bedtime routine, but Eleanor gently reaches out and touches him on the arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Roy looks to Franklin, who nods it's all right, and exits. Eleanor closes the door and puts the candle on the bureau. A fter a beat, Franklin begins to unbuckle his pants. He then lies back on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is your most pressing concern? Eleanor kneels before him and tugs the pants down, slowly, so as not to catch on the braces. Eleanor folds the pants and carefully places them over the back of a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Getting a doctor to live on the premises full-time. Someone who, at the very least, could monitor our progress. Make us legitimate. She begins to take off Franklin's braces -- a series of intricate buckles. Eleanor slides the braces off his legs. His legs, though now deeply tanned are withered and spindly. He is still wearing his shoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that costs more money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Eleanor puts the heavy braces against the wall and kneels once again to untie his shoelaces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the real problem is no one is interested. The annual Orthopedics Convention is being held in Atlanta this weekend and I offered to speak. (his anger surfacing) They turned me down flat. Eleanor takes Franklin's pajama bottoms off the bed and with tender care pulls them up his legs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few weeks ago, the conditions at a garment factory on West 27th Street were brought to my attention. The owners claimed everything was satisfactory, but would never let anyone in to conduct a proper inspection. She reaches for Franklin's hands and pulls him up to a seated position. They are now face to face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It took awhile, but we finally got in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We? He searches her face for clues as to the woman she's become. He starts to unbutton his shirt and put on his pajama top. Eleanor sits in a chair across from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I showed up with someone from the Labor Board and we refused to leave until they let us in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you suggesting?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the risk of my good standing with the Junior Assistance League, I suggest we crash the party. She stands and walks over to Franklin and runs her hand through his hair.    E LEANOR Good night, Franklin. She goes to the door and opens it letting in a shaft of light against the candle-lit room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night, Babs. She blows the candle out and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: EXT. ATLANTA STREET - DAY 108                                                            108 Franklin's car pulls up to a massive stone building built in Greek revival style. Franklin looks intimidated -- there are two dozen stairs leading up to the main entrance. EXT. CONVENTION CENTER - CONTINUOUS 109                                                            109 Roy climbs the stairs like a stevedore with Franklin slung over his shoulder. Using enormous force, Eleanor is pulling the chair up and over each step while walking backwards up the stairs. INT. AMPHITHEATER - DAY 110                                                            110 The stage is lit with a skeleton hanging on a stand and large projections on a screen of spinal discs while a DOCTOR, in a dull litany, intones a prepared speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A clinical situation where the radicular or nerve root is compressed by the prolapsed disc is referred to as a radiculopathy. Double doors fly open with a BANG as all heads turn to see Franklin and Eleanor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So sorry we're late!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good afternoon! Eleanor talks quickly while wheeling Franklin down the aisle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eleanor Roosevelt, niece of the late President Theodore Roosevelt and this is my husband, Franklin, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you sure this worked on 27th Street?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It seemed to at the time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . They reach the befuddled Doctor on stage whose name tag reads, "Dr. Bissell."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Dr. Bissell for agreeing to let us share the stage with you today. It was so generous of you. Dr. Bissell smiles limply, saving face. The audience vaguely applauds. Franklin and Eleanor are now center stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My husband, as many of you may have read, is a victim of polio. However, victim is only a definition, not a state of mind. Franklin? He looks at her completely amazed. Eleanor gives him an F encouraging nod to take over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We all know that poor circulation is a chronic problem for limbs damaged by polio... I've never been able to swim more than a few minutes without becoming too cold. But there's a place, gentlemen... a miraculous place not three hours from here where the water is filled with natural minerals at a temperature of almost 90 degrees. That place, gentlemen, is called Warm Springs. CLOSE-UP One DOCTOR in particular, 60's, leans forward in his chair, listening with great interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patients can stay in these waters for up to an hour. This is essential in allowing them the time to work on strengthening their muscles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have come to the shared conclusion that research for the cause and the cure for infantile paralysis is paramount. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . However, until NOR(cont'd)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: more emphasis has be placed on rehabilitation. We personally invite you to Warm Springs to come and take a look. Thank you. ON THE AUDIENCE These "men of science" are mesmerized by Eleanor's style, both warm and immediate. She has disarmed them with her lack of pretension. ON FRANKLIN and ELEANOR Their two separate journeys intersecting -- lightning in a bottle. INT. LOBBY - DAY 111                                                            111 There is a receiving line in place to get a last word or an autograph with Franklin and Eleanor. DR. WILLIS, bespectacled, speaks with them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw you speak at the Legion Hall in Cleveland last Spring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the League of Women Voters?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You created quite a stir. Not sure you'll be asked back. Franklin is ready to intervene but Eleanor puts her hand on E his shoulder stopping him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I believe you must say what you feel in your heart -- what you feel is right, for you'll be criticized anyway. Damned if you do
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: damned if you don't. DR. HEBERT, military in bearing -- the doctor who listened so intensely -- steps up in line and shakes hands with Eleanor and then Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Peter Hebert. I've been doing my own studies in this area. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it is possible I'd like to come and make an evaluation for the Journal of Orthopedic Medicine. Franklin looks to Eleanor, elated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sooner the better. EXT. FRANKLIN'S CAR - TWILIGHT 112                                                               112 Roy is fast asleep tucked around the wheelchair in the back seat. Franklin smiles in Eleanor's direction. She looks back at him shyly and smiles in return. But her expression changes when she sees something in his eyes -- something she hasn't seen for a long time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you? Franklin reaches out and takes her hand, pulling her close. He stretches his whole arm around her and places her hand on one of the driving knobs, his hand on top of hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know how to drive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll teach you. They operate the car together -- their connection complete. EXT. TRAIN STATION - DAY 113                                                               113 Franklin and Eleanor are sitting in the front seat of the car. Louis is already up on the train platform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll break the news to Mama. Franklin smiles as they look at each other like two naughty children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it's going to be fun. Eleanor bursts out laughing, Franklin joins in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Babs... words fail me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You? Franklin Roosevelt? She leans in and kisses Franklin on the mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do so love you. She slides out of the car and goes up to the platform and A boards the train while Franklin watches her. Farmer and his Wife from the school house graduation approach Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Roosevelt you lookin' mighty fit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine day, isn't it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is. How's the Boll Weevil situation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I expect the Boll Weevil is always gonna be a situation, Mr. Roosevelt, but thanks for askin'. Franklin's energy and vitality are infectious. The politician within him is being reborn. INT. TRAIN CAR - DAY 114                                                               114 A beaming Eleanor sits down next to Louis. He too is looking very pleased. Eleanor takes notice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do I get the feeling we're not smiling about the same thing? The train begins pulling out. They both look out at Franklin. Locals are coming up to his car surrounding him -- he is a magnet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. STATE ASSEMBLY, N.Y. - VIEWING SECTION - DAY 115                                                               115 Louis is seated in the front row of the balcony of the State Assembly, his feet up on the railing, eating pistachio nuts. Also seated are two politicos, JAMES HASTINGS and STEPHEN TELLER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't kiss babies from a wheelchair. It'll scare their mothers half to death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Al Smith's got a lock on the presidential nomination.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Correct me if I'm wrong, but don't you think even after all these years that old Al's still a little rough around the edges? They laugh knowing this is a huge understatement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin can help soften his image.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let him put Smith's name in nomination. Teller and Hastings are none to sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, he is a helluva speech maker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, but is your man up to it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's in the bag, guys. Count on it. Bluffing is one of Louis's strong suits and it looks like they're buying it. Just then, Louis notices a familiar face down on the floor. I S 91.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Stansbury, give my best to the Misses! (to Hastings and Teller) He's lost weight. Must've been the prison food. 1 INT. MERIWETHER INN - HALLWAY - MORNING 16                                                               116 A line stretches outside with patients waiting to be seen. Among them is Franklin, chatting with everyone else, expecting and receiving no priority attention. INT. MERIWETHER INN - DAY ROOM - MORNING 117                                                               117 Dr. Hebert is examining Daisy. Helena is by his side, filling him in on her case history. INT. MERIWETHER INN - NIGHT 118                                                               118 Helena, dressed in a robe, walks the halls of the Inn. Something is amiss. EXT. GROUNDS - NIGHT 119                                                               119 An empty wheelchair, illuminated by a sliver of moonlight. On a blanket nearby are Jake and Mary Beth. he unbuttons his shirt and runs her hands over his impressively developed upper body. They begin to kiss hungrily, passionately -- completely in their own world. Several yards away, across the lawn, Eloise is in Woodhall's arms -- they are dancing. He is singing softly into her ear as they sway, her feet never touching the ground. NT. MERIWETHER INN - NIGHT Helena, in a nightgown, is looking out a window into the distance. Fiercely protective and slightly envious of her charges, she pulls a pack of cigarettes from her bathrobe pocket and steals a solitary smoke. EXT. COTTAGE - NIGHT 120                                                               120 Franklin seated alone on the porch in the darkness. He drags on his cigarette and the red glow illuminates the contours of his face in repose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 92. INT. MERIWETHER INN - FRONT DESK - DAY 121                                                            121 Franklin is on the phone. Roy stands by his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Souders. How are you?... Couldn't be better. I was wondering if you'd found a buyer for my naval prints? (clearly not) I see. Well, they're in marvelous condition... All right, Souders. Oh one more thing... I have some beautiful pieces of my Grandfather's -- T'ang Dynasty... Really?... An auction in the Fall? That sounds promising. I'll be in touch. Franklin hangs up and sits deep in thought. He rubs his perspiring forehead with the back of his hand. He looks down at his hand and sees that it is shaking. EXT. GROUNDS - DAY 122                                                            122 Franklin is walking on crutches aided by Roy. Nearby, a group of children practice on parallel bars with Helena.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What am I going to tell these people if I have to close things down?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That you did the best you could. Franklin gives Roy a look of gratitude, then notices Lionel approaching with his mail bag. Lionel hands Franklin a fistful of open envelopes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any good news?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Creditors are gettin' cranky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The operative word was good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yah, almost forgot. The doctor that came and studied ya'll sent his report.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Lionel offers up the envelope, but then pulls it back before handing it over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Save me the stamps? Franklin nods then grabs it from Lionel. He rips it open and begins devouring the report.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... therefore, in conclusion, my research has shown that the overwhelming majority of patients here have shown some improvement. Enough for me to recommend warm water therapy as the standard post polio treatment to the Orthopedics Society of America!" ( he grips Roy's arm) Roy! Something catches Franklin's eye and his smile begins to fade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, sir? INT. COTTAGE - NIGHT 123                                                               123 Helena entering the cottage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not as bad as you think. Franklin slams the door behind her and wheels over to the table. He throws back a drink -- clearly not his first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Read it. Out loud. Page twenty-nine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I already...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Read it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Of the twenty three patients examined only one, a forty-four year old male, showed little visible signs of improvement..." This is one doctor's opinion, Franklin. H
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep reading.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "There is marked falling away of the muscle masses on either side of the spine in the lower lumbar region. His lower extremities present a most depressing picture." She brings the pages down, but Franklin gestures her to continue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: feel after studying him that the psychological factor in his management is paramount. He has such courage and ambition. Yet at the same time he is such an extraordinarily sensitive emotional mechanism... It is difficult for her to continue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... that it will take all the skill which we can muster to lead him successfully to a recognition of his severe physical limitations without crushing him."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patronizing son-of-a-bitch! I wanted to walk again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you still might. This report legitimizes we've worked so hard for. We can raise funs now. It could change everything!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It won't change anything for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin, I won't play this game. I won't feel sorry for you. e reaches for the bottle, but Helena grabs on to it, stopping him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I met a boy today, ten years old. He's paralyzed from the waist down. Why don't you go regale him with vivid tales about your trips to Europe and playing football at school. Tell him how you courted your wife and fathered children. Tell him of a life he can only dream of. ( a beat) I can't help you out of a hole if I climb in with you. Then we're both stuck. INT. MERIWETHER INN - FRONT DESK - DAY Fred, wearing a bow tie and an oversized jacket, is proudly polishing off a desktop sign that reads: "FRED BOTTS: DIRECTOR OF ADMISSIONS." Helena is behind him reading a file.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (entering) Here's another one he's refusin'. He throws a telegram onto an already large stack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you read it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't like telegrams. All them
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and stuff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make you dizzy, Lionel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little bit. Fred eyes the telegram, then impulsively grabs it, ripping it open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Would be honored if you place my name in nomination for President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The party needs you. STOP. Yours sincerely, Al Smith."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's he? (
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Governor of New York. handing it to Lionel) Why don't you slide it under his door?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. Probably slide it right back. Lionel leaves. Fred and Helena are silent for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't go. He doesn't want to be seen walking on crutches or being wheeled to the podium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The millions listening on radio won't be able to see that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But all the people at the convention will. Helena nods, "That's right."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. COTTAGE - AFTERNOON 125                                                              125 Responding to a knock at the door, Roy gets up from sitting on the couch with Franklin, sullen and inattentive. H e opens the door to Louis who walks right in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good afternoon, Mr. Howe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Roy. Roy takes his hat and coat and exits to the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't believe you've made me come all the way back to this hell hole!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've done no such thing. F
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here to take you to Houston. You started your speech yet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not going. He stares at Franklin, drinking. Shaking his head, he goes over to the sidebar and pours one for himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what this is, don't you? It's a golden opportunity. A springboard for you to run for Governor. ranklin is silent. Frustrated, Louis takes a seat in Franklin's empty wheelchair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ever hear of a Civil War General named Francis Nicholls?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I never heard of him either. But this was one brave son-of-a- bitch. Fought for the Confederacy and lost his left arm in one battle and his left foot in another. Then after the war he ran and won the Governorship of Louisiana -- twice!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was a war hero.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with emphasis) Twice. (a beat) Look, I've worked like a dog to keep your name in play, grovelling at the feet of the powers-that-be in back rooms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As much for you as for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be damned if I'm going to let you pass up a chance like this. It's time -- and you're ready. EXT. COTTAGE - AFTERNOON 126                                                               126 Waiting on the porch are Eleanor and Helena, who are seated, talking. Louis exits the cottage, defeated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your turn. Eleanor rises and goes into the cottage as Louis takes her seat next to Helena. INT. COTTAGE - CONTINUING 127                                                               127 ELEANOR Roy, so good to see you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very good to see you, Mrs. Roosevelt. She approaches a surprised Franklin. Leaning in, she runs a hand across his stubbly beard. He looks up at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a mess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The report. I'll never... She sits by his side and Franklin begins to cry. His sobs grow louder connecting to the despair deep inside him. It unleashes an avalanche of grief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my darling...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm useless, Eleanor. I feel so useless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not true. No one can make you feel inferior without your consent. Finally, his sobs subside. F E 99.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have done a brilliant thing here -- a magnificent thing. Eleanor picks up the E doctor's report and puts it in the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's get you in the water. EXT. THE POOL - DAY 128                                                               128 Franklin is wheeled down to the pool by Roy and Eleanor. When they get closer, Franklin makes out someone already swimming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Pop!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (squinting) Who's that? ELLIOT ROOSEVELT is now 17 years old. He has his mother's enormous blue eyes and his father's natural charisma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elliot!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on! You getting in? Louis and Helena approach the pool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sense a conspiracy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ain't seen nothin' yet. ranklin smiles, warily. EXT. A CLEARING - DAY 129                                                               129 Elliot is climbing a rope dangling high from a tree as Franklin and Eleanor look up at him. Franklin is standing on crutches. Elliot descends with a flourish as Helena approaches Franklin with a single cane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin, let go of your crutches. You're not going to need them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going to make your arms function as your legs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is that possible?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elliot, go to your father and stand on his left side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think this may work, Pop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eleanor, take the crutch. Eleanor takes one crutch as Helena takes the other, replacing it in Franklin's hand with a cane. Then, with Elliot on Franklin's left side she bends Elliot's arm at a right angle, like a parallel bar, and hooks Franklin's left arm around his. Going over to Franklin's right side she puts a cane in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Franklin) Now use your right shoulder and pull your left leg forward. He does so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good! Now with the muscles in your left shoulder, pull your right leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One small bump and I'll land right on my keister!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what Elliot is for. He's going to hold you up. Hitch your leg! Come on! Franklin and Elliot attempt to walk. It requires immense strength and effort on both their parts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (ever the taskmaster) Elliot, don't lean in -- stand up straight. Pull against him. He needs you! After one or two steps the enormity of it overwhelms Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm strong, pop. You can't hurt me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can do this, Franklin! Keep going! They start the walk again. It's awkward... difficult... but it's working.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (under his breath) I'll be damned. Franklin stops, exhausted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin, are you all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine. I'm just... Roy runs in with a chair and helps Franklin into it as Helena, Eleanor, Louis, Elliot and Roy all look at him, concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This isn't a replacement for the real work we're doing to get you on your feet again, understand? No one is throwing in the towel or even agreeing with that doctor's report...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it's not practical -- F H 102.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's not. (a beat) It's political. Franklin looks at Louis, then to Eleanor, and realizes that this could be it. 1 EXT. GROUNDS - AFTERNOON 30                                                               130 Franklin and Elliot are walking. Helena is close behind, coaching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Use Elliot, not the cane. Switch your weight to Elliot... good! Keep your head up. Off to the side Pat, Jake, Eloise, Woodhall and Daisy are having an informal picnic, observing Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is he working so hard to hide it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't have a choice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I disagree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you disagree? "There but for the grace of God goes us," that's what they're saying. As if our bodies is who we are, but it's not. It's our souls is who we are, but they don't know that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish he could just wheel himself out there in front of everybody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't do that Eloise, it's politics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not gonna matter if he hides his legs as long as he don't hide what he knows. And what he knows is what it's like to be one of us. ranklin, getting closer, raises his cane in greeting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good afternoon, everyone! Off-balance Franklin goes down hard bringing Elliot down with him. Eleanor, Louis and Roy all rush to his aid, but Helena is there first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a moment to catch your breath...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn. You okay son?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine, Pop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You fell down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I did, Daisy. Twelfth time today. Must be a new record! Daisy laughs as do the others, though some can't hide their concern. Franklin struggles hard as Roy and Elliot help him to his feet. 131
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COTTAGE - NIGHT Eleanor is packing Franklin's suitcase while Franklin, sitting up in bed dressed in pajamas, works on his speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And so America must find... ( reconsidering) No, America needs a pathfinder... Louis, pacing in shirtsleeves, nods approvingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To emblaze the trail along a high road that will avoid... avoid the bottomless morass... Discouraged, Franklin pushes aside the pages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it? What's wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if I fall... trying to get to the podium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you fall, you show them how to get up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, if I fall in front of thousands of people I lose everything but their pity. (a beat) They'll be writing my obituary before I get up off the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elliot won't let you fall, he'll be there. All the arrangements have been made, boss. It'll be fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are we fooling? This will never work. They'll never let me back into politics. They'll never see past my legs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My darling, they'll never see past your legs unless you do. 132
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MERIWETHER INN - MORNING Franklin is settling into the driver's seat of his car, aided by Roy. Eleanor is seated next to him; Louis and Elliot in back. Franklin's attention is diverted by something he sees straight ahead. It is the entire Warm Springs group coming down the driveway in chairs and on crutches. All the patients, the Push Boys, the physical therapists, Helena, Jake, Fred, Aunt Sally, Eloise and Lionel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, Doc -- we're not coming with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you'll be with me. No question of that. (a beat) I am proud more than you will ever know to be part of this community. (his voice growing stronger) A community based not on birthright or privilege, but on compassion and courage. The true power of these waters is that they brought us all together. Our ability to help one another is what will make our victory over polio endure. Our ability to survive... despite the odds. F ranklin looks out at the sea of faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What we have done and will continue to do until this disease is defeated is come together -- like a family -- and do what we do best... (his voice breaking) Lift each other up. Franklin starts the car as the crowd begins to disperse. Then, spying Helena, Franklin calls out to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Mahoney I need to speak with you, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, Doc. Off her smile, Franklin reaches into his pocket and withdraws a small box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. He hands it to Helena. She just stares at it, at a loss for words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open it. She does so, tentatively, revealing a ladies watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't wear it in the pool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll try not to. Good luck, Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm throwing myself to the wolves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've faced worse. And if they bite, you can come back here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll always come back here. Helena steps away and Franklin pulls out and down the driveway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 133                                                             133 INT. HOUSTON TRAIN STATION - NIGHT Dark and deserted Roy is carrying Franklin down a flight of stairs. Louis is hastily checking over his shoulder. If possible, Eleanor appears even more nervous than Louis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're being superstitious, Louis. There aren't any reporters here. Suddenly out of the darkness a FLASHBULB POPS revealing a dozen or more REPORTERS staring incomprehensibly at the sight of a six foot, 200 lb. man being carried like a baby in the arms of a black man. No one does or says a thing. The PHOTOGRAPHER who had the wherewithal to snap the one picture raises his camera to take another. But DAN REED, a reporter for The New York Herald Tribune and a gentle giant at over six foot-four, reaches out and places a massive hand over the lens. Slowly, but firmly, he pulls the camera down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Louis and Eleanor stand stock still, tense, watching the scene unfold Roy is sweating; his arms growing weak. Elliot brings the chair around and Roy gently lowers Franklin into it. It's a measure of Reed's standing with this group that his authority is unquestioned. But the Photographer raises his camera again. Only now Reed isn't as kind. He grabs the camera from him and opens the back, pulling out the film and exposing it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good to see you, Mr. Roosevelt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. INT. CONVENTION HALL - HOUSTON - NIGHT 134                                                               134 The enormous arena is empty but for some maintenance WORKERS and JANITORS. Louis enters and makes his way to the stage. He approaches dead center and stands behind the podium looking out. GRIPPING the podium hard he ROCKS it back and forth. Taking no chances, he pulls a hammer out from the rear of his waistband and a bunch of nails from his coat pocket. Looking around to see if anyone is paying any attention to him he quickly ducks down behind the podium. The sound of HAMMERING fills the hall as Louis, on his knees, NAILS the podium to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : INT. CONVENTION HALL - DAY 135                                                               135 Twenty thousand CONVENTIONEERS are roasting in the hall. It is Houston in the summer and it's broiling hot. A sea of hand- held red, white and blue fans are being waved all at once -- most bearing the words "SMITH FOR PRESIDENT." Near the stage is a long table where the new breed of RADIO REPORTERS are seated, each in front of a primitive looking microphone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Hovering in a group off to the side are Dan Reed and the REPORTERS from the previous night. INT. BACKSTAGE - CONTINUING 136                                                               136 Franklin is standing ramrod straight holding onto Elliot's arm. He looks handsome in a navy pin-striped suit. As everyone else is sweating no one notices that Franklin is perspiring more than F most.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is she seated? Louis, a human train wreck himself, reaches over to mop Franklin's brow with a handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a box stage left. Give me your hand. Franklin takes his hand off his cane. It's soaking wet. Louis wipes it, gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Louis, what the hell am I doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Putting your big toe in the water. Just then, a VOICE booms out from the loudspeakers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to introduce to you a man who as Assistant Secretary of the Navy served our country with distinction. member of an illustrious family of long-standing political commitment to our great nation... Ladies and gentlemen: Franklin Delano Roosevelt! Franklin turns to Elliot and they both take deep breaths.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go. The curtains part and they begin moving forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. THE STAGE OF THE DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION - CONTINUING 137 137 A BLINDING SPOTLIGHT picks up Franklin and Elliot. The SPOTLIGHT follows them as they make their way to the podium. Franklin is hitching each leg forward, slowly. The tip of his cane hits the floor with pinpoint accuracy for balance and support. He leans heavily on Elliot's arm. The walk appears effortless. He chats with Elliot the whole way, still managing to flash the CONVENTIONEERS his million dollar smile. But the walk is slow and the ovation is beginning to fade. 138   L                                                        138 INT. BACKSTAGE - CONTINUING ouis stands in the wings clutching the curtain with one hand and covering his eyes with the other. INT. DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION BOX - CONTINUING 139                                                            139 Eleanor sits looking down at her lap, afraid to even breathe. INT. THE STAGE - CONTINUING 140                                                            140 Franklin and Elliot are still ten steps away from the podium. Sensing the crowd noise weakening, he whispers to Elliot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laugh as if I'm making a joke. Elliot throws back his head and laughs. The crowd, wanting to be in on it, rise as one in a sustained CHEER! But a puddle of sweat caused by the dripping perspiration from Franklin's hands is causing the tip of his cane to slip. Elliot, ever aware, grips him tighter, averting disaster and finally they reach the podium. Franklin grabs one side of the podium while Elliot, with a sleight of hand Houdini would admire, LOCKS his father's braces, whisks the cane away, pulls his father's speech from his breast pocket and lays it smoothly on the podium. THE VIEW FROM BEHIND displays how Franklin's legs are spread wide for stability as he clutches the podium. He holds on tightly, as if the wood might snap from his grip. FROM OUT FRONT the crowd sees only a powerful man standing tall amidst the flashbulbs POPPING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Franklin has made it. He is home. INT. MERIWETHER INN - LOBBY - CONTINUOUS 141                                                            141 All the denizens of Warm Springs are crowded around the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here on the stage is Franklin Roosevelt... a figure tall and proud even in suffering; a face of classic profile; a frame nervous and yet self-controlled. A man softened, cleansed and illumined with pain. 1 42   INT. WARWICK HOTEL, HOUSTON - SMITH'S SUITE - CONTINUOUS 142 GOVERNOR AL SMITH, 51, is seated by a radio, surrounded by CRONIES. An overblown Irishman with gold capped teeth and heavy New York accent. He chomps on a lit cigar that never leaves the side of his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell of an ovation, Al. Couldn't have asked for anything more. Smith sits silently puffing on his cigar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You may have to be careful though. Looks like you're raising up a rival.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark my words. He'll be dead in a year. INT. DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION BOX - CONTINUING 143                                                            143 Eleanor applauds Franklin as a REPORTER leans in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Roosevelt, one last question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think polio has affected your husband's mind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I do. I certainly do.
direction.name: direction
